openstackclient/compute/v2/flavor.py.message:
I included sort_attr to try and make this work. But why are we exposing sort key in a find_min_match method in osc_lib? I know find_min_match() uses sort_items() in osc_lib which requires a sort_str, but that can be easily constructed from the flair (constraints) dict. The keys in the flair dict (ram, disk, vcpus) are the keys the iterable needs to be sorted on and always in ascending order. 

Examples:

1. flair = {'ram': 2048, 'disk': 1, vcpus: 2} will result in a sort key of 'ram:asc, disk:asc, vcpus:asc'. 

2. flair = {'ram: 2048'} will result in a sort key of 'ram:asc'. The other keys don't matter here for the sort since the output isn't constrained by them. 

Basically, someone using find_min_match() shouldn't care about what keys are used internally for sorting when invoking the function. They just expect a minimum match given the constraints.

There is a more efficient way to do this for ram and disk, the GET /flavors API has filter parameters for minRam and minDisk:

https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#list-flavors

same with GET /flavors/detail.

Unfortunately we don't have the same filter parameter for minCpu but you could at least use the existing filter parameters if --vcpus isn't specified but one or both of the others are.

monasca_agent/collector/checks_d/libvirt.message:
Looks good but I did have a question on these lines.  This seems to -1 all the constants to generate keys for the dict.  We also seem to apply a -1 to the dom_status variable in _inspect_state so I'm assuming the -1 to the constants here is to let things line up properly with that function.

I'm wondering if it's worth while to have these -1 values scattered about or if we should just return the dom_state value that matches the libvirt constants from _inspect_state and adjust the reported metrics in _inspect_state appropriately.

You're right. For the aggregate metrics the -1 is definitely not needed (The numeric value of the key is only used as an index to associate a libvirt status value with a symbolic name. It really does not matter whether this index is shifted by -1. I removed this and changed the return value of _inspect_state() to the unaltered libvirt status now.

+1

_inspect_state is used only once, so changing the return value will not hurt. Joe's suggestions seems cleaner.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ma.message: Can you add a comment about what the purpose of this file is?
This class appears to be doing much more than just reconfiguring the OAM endpoint. Is restricting this to being executed only on oam config changes going to break other things?
This manifest is also run during bootstrap/bootstrap replay (networking related changes) to reconfigure service endpoints
Yes, this class also configures distributed cloud endpoints, i can't recall if this is the code path that needs to trigger it though

This is being run separately via  sysinv/conductor/manager.py:: reconfigure_service_endpoints().  It would not be sufficient to do it here because this code path was/is gated - previously only run once based on /var/run and replay doesnt clear this.  Also, verified DistributedCloud system controller and subcloud install ok and deploy status complete and insync with this update.  There are also no RegionOne endpoints in subcloud openstack endpoint list (as they're deleted by the keystone::endpoint::runtime).

There are several problems in xdpyinfo:
1) To run in GUI Display must be correct, for example, running firefox inside docker with GUI (e.g. Zelenium), the display is :99.0.

2) xorg (the minimum package requirement from X11) must be installed.

question: When we use the headless mode, should DISPLAY be 0.0? Or does it work even if DISPLAY is not 0.0?

If you add DISPLAY to [testenv:integartion] passenv per my comment in tox.ini, the above question would be considered.

If required, we can set "display" to "0.0" if IS_SELENIUM_HEADLESS is true.

When using SELENIUM_HEADLESS=1 (in tox), the DISPLAY value does not matter. 
When using SELENIUM_HEADLESS=0 (in tox), the DISPLAY value must refer to the current DISPLAY. Usually it is ":0.0" (default for local execution), but on remote hosts with X11 it can be different display (e.g. inside my docker it is :99.0).

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo-container-.message:
Bogdan is right. We worked on similar bug in paunch. There is a race during delete operation. "force" removes container while device is still present.

The pattern that worked is 

podman container stop && podman container rm  || podman container rm --force

the "stop" is supposed to be managed by systemd... or shall we re-add a stop here? but with the &&, it will probably fail and won't hit the "podman rm" and directly go to the "rm --force"
We can't 100% mimic what was in paunch :/. "retries" can't be applied to a block, which would allow to mimic the whole thing
to follow the paunch's pattern, it should retry a three-step action: podman container stop && rm || rm -f

that's the closer we can get to what paunch did - at least with my current knowledge. Feel free to propose a modification.

A patch using this change is here:
https://review.opendev.org/725545

Lets include this description in the spec too.

I feel that it would be better to have more than one fields from UX pov. Actually 3 labels to be exact.

The fields I would like to have would be:

* overridden_labels: labels that exist in both parent and object labels but have different value

* added_labels: labels that do not exist in the parent labels and were added in the object

* skipped_labels: labels that exist in the parent dict but do not exist in the object's labels. Specifically, this field will be used when the user did not provide the --override-labels (used the current functionality) and did not provide some of the labels that exist in the parent.

 > even if you don't pass anything in the cli, the client will send
 > the value that is default in the API.
 > 
 > 
 > [0] https://github.com/openstack/python-magnumclient/blob/5b7a67131920f42b2add9ad0d063e5d9ff01b611/magnumclient/osc/v1/cluster_templates.py#L208
 > 
 > 
 > A1.
 > a. Make override-labels true by default (the cli doesn't send
 > anything if nothing is specified).
 > b. Big flashing reno that old client will change behaviour.
 > c. Give deployments the option with a config option to preserve old
 > default functionality. The minority of deployments will want to do
 > this. It is still a breaking change, but the minority of users will
 > want to change to the old behaviour.

This also sounds like the best option to me but only for default option when nothing is specified via CLI. This means we  will need, as well as --override-labels, also something like --do-not-override-labels option so that the user can request the exact behaviour if they need to. 

 > 
 > A2.
 > a. Make override-labels false by default (the cli doesn't send
 > anything if nothing is specified).
 > c. Give deployments the option with a config option to change it.
 > This is not a breaking change, but upstream api-ref won't be the
 > source of truth for the API.
 > 

I agree this would be the safest. But I can imaging it will be bad UX if users need to specify --override-labels flag most of the time.

 > B.
 > Control the default in the client (for environments where the the
 > ops team controls the clients) or have a different default than the
 > API.
 > 
 > Surpisingly (even to myself), I prefer to break the API (A1) and
 > allow operators to "unbreak" it. Most operators will want this new
 > default. Also, not having a default in the cli is a move towards
 > the right direction.
 > 
 > Finally, what we can do, is hard code in the CLI and ui, what is
 > the maximum API version they can use. i.e. Train client  will send
 > by default the maximum train API microversion when it was released.
 > ATM it sends latest.

Sure, I was wondering why we were using "latest" and have encountered issues because of this in the past.

 > 
 > What do you think?

Personally, I prefer A2, and leave the option to cloud provider. Because it's a config option, which mean the cloud provider can make the decision if they want to break the compatibility.

However, if both of you guys are happy to go for A1, I'm OK with that. And obviously, we need a big warning in the release note.

Both options look ok to me. The main thing is as mentioned above we force users to provide this flag every time they create a cluster.

A minor thing as people will get use to it, but `override-labels` still does not sound like the best name - overriding sounds like replacing to me (not a native speaker), i would expect setting it to True would replace the cluster template labels completely. In reality we're merging the provided values with what's coming from the cluster template.

Small thing though, whatever you decide is ok.

Although it is not good as a design principle to change behaviour of an API via a config option, I see that we want to lift user's pain. Keep in mind that the clients (ui/cli) have defaults too. So to control this in the API only we should not send anything to the API, same as what an old client would do (the old client won't send override-labels since it doesn't know about it). e.g. here [0], even if you don't pass anything in the cli, the client will send the value that is default in the API.


[0] https://github.com/openstack/python-magnumclient/blob/5b7a67131920f42b2add9ad0d063e5d9ff01b611/magnumclient/osc/v1/cluster_templates.py#L208


A1.
a. Make override-labels true by default (the cli doesn't send anything if nothing is specified).
b. Big flashing reno that old client will change behaviour.
c. Give deployments the option with a config option to preserve old default functionality. The minority of deployments will want to do this. It is still a breaking change, but the minority of users will want to change to the old behaviour.

A2.
a. Make override-labels false by default (the cli doesn't send anything if nothing is specified).
c. Give deployments the option with a config option to change it. This is not a breaking change, but upstream api-ref won't be the source of truth for the API.

B.
Control the default in the client (for environments where the the ops team controls the clients) or have a different default than the API. 

Surpisingly (even to myself), I prefer to break the API (A1) and allow operators to "unbreak" it. Most operators will want this new default. Also, not having a default in the cli is a move towards the right direction.

Finally, what we can do, is hard code in the CLI and ui, what is the maximum API version they can use. i.e. Train client will send by default the maximum train API microversion when it was released. ATM it sends latest.

What do you think?

> Both options look ok to me. The main thing is as mentioned above we
 > force users to provide this flag every time they create a cluster.
 > 
 > A minor thing as people will get use to it, but `override-labels`
 > still does not sound like the best name - overriding sounds like
 > replacing to me (not a native speaker), i would expect setting it
 > to True would replace the cluster template labels completely. In
 > reality we're merging the provided values with what's coming from
 > the cluster template.
 > 
 > Small thing though, whatever you decide is ok.

The naming of `override-labels` has been an ongoing debate but I think the team is now largely on the same page that override_labels=true is the new behaviour and override_labels=false is the old behavior. The definition of the old action is "do no override but the inherited labels, instead replace them completely" and the new action is "override the inherited labels with provided labels".
s/we force users to provide this flag/we *do not* force users to provide this flag/. Bad bad typo.

Let's do A2 then which is safe.

I share the opinion that passing an the --override-labesl argument is major improvement actually and a minor annoyance from a UX perspective. eg At CERN we have 26 labels in our latest public CT for example that the users needs to carry.


The override verb used in the argment is not intuitive, but the logic is not that intuitive anyway. Even in software development the concept is not the most obvious :).


Regardless of the name we choose, the help message and docs is the most imporant which clarifies what the API is going to do. Effectively a dict update.
I shared the same comments as Ricardo as a non-native English speaker. Is 'merged_labels' an option? But this is not a blocker.

We can do merge. The important part will be the help message and API reference.

In Computer Science, method overriding [0][1] can replace completely the parent function or the new implementation could execute both the parent and child logic. In a way, the logic we have now [2] in the API, is overriding. In English, the logic we propose is not overriding according to the dictionary [7].

We can say that merge [6] is more accurate because this [3] code snippet is described [4] frequently as merge. The python documentation for dict.update mentions "overwriting for existing keys" [5], overwrite [8] applies only for existing keys.

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/boots.message: Can you confirm the use of the single quotes in this command?  It may work fine, but I just bring it up because it doesn't match the other task commands.
Your change looks good. It was done this way deliberately to handle all cases.

Stylistically, it was copied from the pattern in this block from bringup_kubemaster.yml which is where I initially looked at making the change as the loopback_ip is determined above this block.

- name: Update Kube admin yaml with network info
  command: "{{ item }}"
  args:
    warn: false
  with_items:
    - "sed -i -e 's|<%= @apiserver_advertise_address %>|'$CLUSTER_IP'|g' /etc/kubernetes/kubeadm.yaml"
    - "sed -i -e 's|<%= @etcd_endpoint %>|'$ETCD_ENDPOINT'|g' /etc/kubernetes/kubeadm.yaml"
    - "sed -i -e 's|<%= @service_domain %>|'cluster.local'|g' /etc/kubernetes/kubeadm.yaml"
    - "sed -i -e 's|<%= @pod_network_cidr %>|'$POD_NETWORK_CIDR'|g' /etc/kubernetes/kubeadm.yaml"
    - "sed -i -e 's|<%= @service_network_cidr %>|'$SERVICE_NETWORK_CIDR'|g' /etc/kubernetes/kubeadm.yaml"
    - "sed -i -e 's|<%= @ctrl_mgr_flex_vol_plugin_dir %>|'$VOLUME_PLUGIN_DIR'|g' /etc/kubernetes/kubeadm.yaml"
  environment:
    CLUSTER_IP: "{{ cluster_floating_address }}"
    ETCD_ENDPOINT: "http://{{ cluster_floating_address | ipwrap }}:2379"
    POD_NETWORK_CIDR: "{{ cluster_pod_subnet }}"
    SERVICE_NETWORK_CIDR: "{{ cluster_service_subnet }}"
    VOLUME_PLUGIN_DIR: "{{ kubelet_vol_plugin_dir }}"

ovsdbapp/schema/open_vswitch/helpers.py.message:
This is clearly a better argument name--the only thing I worry about is that ovsdbapp is not used just in OpenStack projects, so theoretically this would be an API change that could break existing code (though it seems unlikely). Not sure if it is worth doing:

 probe = kwargs.pop('set_timeout', kwargs.pop('inactivity_probe', None))

to handle either?

Right, I didn't think about this. I just made a search in http://codesearch.openstack.org/.

This is indeed breaking the current API. I'll add your solution.
from original code it seems 'set_timeout' is a bool parameter
It is, you are right. I need to refactor this. Good catch!!

But now I review the code, the old code needs to be changed.

"timeout" (the command timeout) is in seconds, the probe timeout is defined in milliseconds. The current code works but not in the way it should.
for probe shouldn't exact 'inactivity_probe' be prioritized over timeout/set_timeout?

Neutron does not use "set_timeout". If any other project is calling this method and "set_timeout" is defined, "timeout * 1000) will be set. Instead of this, Neutron will use only "inactivity_probe".

Anyway, because both are exclusive parameters (set_timeout / inactivity_probe) and Neutron is only going to call this method with the second one, the parameter prevalence won't matter. Any other project will keep the current behavior.

About the API, we need to be careful with "kwargs" because is also used in the command execution:
  return execute(cmd, **kwargs).rstrip()

Any extra argument added should be removed first.
I guess need to change kwargs.get('set_timeout') -> kwargs.pop('set_timeout', None) as well

We should keep the current API: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/720785/2/ovsdbapp/schema/open_vswitch/helpers.py@33

However, with this patch we are not keeping 100% the old API. We are assigning to "probe" the timeout but converting the units.

But kwargs allows us to keep API, doesn't it? I meant change to:

probe = kwargs.pop('inactivity_probe', timeout * 1000 if kwargs.get('set_timeout') else None)

Just a nit anyway.

We have to check this to None otherwise we'll be never able to turn the probe off with the inactivity_probe parameter. From http://www.openvswitch.org/support/dist-docs/ovs-vswitchd.conf.db.5.txt

A value of 0 disables inactivity probes.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ma.message: Migration of hiera data should be done on the release N+1 side (see migrate_hiera_data in controllerconfig/upgrades/controller.py). That code is already migrating the static yaml files from release N. Why doesn't that work for this case? Why can't this migration be done on the N+1 side?

I think there are 2 different types of data. one of them is the data that is backward compatible, which just needs to carry on to the N+1 (and N+1 will convert it to new version). For the other type of data (that's not backward compatible), they need to be massaged (upgraded) before being consumed by N+1. 
In this case the data is more on the 1st type, the format of certificate are well-defined open standard, they don't change often and if they do, they would most likely be backward compatible. The upgrade of the standard will be an in-version upgrade, i.e, release N+1 will retrieve secret data in old standard from release N, then internally (in N+1) to upgrade to new standard.
I think it is a good idea to enable N+1 controller-1 accessing kubernetes cluster of release N, but in this case, it does not provide extra help.

If the dc-adminep-root-ca-certificate may be updated over the upgrade, then it would need to be obtained (via kube_get_secret) prior to the host-unlock.  
Bin, please confirm whether this data needs to obtained on the host-unlock or can migrate the data on N+1 side as part of the prior host-upgrade step.

The certificate data has a renewal cycle. The current solution is to ensure the k8s secret (managed by cert-manager) is the only source that the controller to get the data from, therefor the secret is most up-to-date.

OK - we need to take a step back here. Our current approach means that every time we add a piece of hiera data that is sourced from the kubernetes database, we're going to have to patch something to release N-1 so that we can generate that hiera data during the upgrade. This is not sustainable.

I think a possible solution would be to give controller-1 access to the kubernetes API during the upgrade, so it can retrieve any data it needs and write it into its own hiera data as part of the existing code that generates hiera data. I think the solution might look something like this:
- When upgrade is started, controller-0 will make a copy of the /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf file that controller-1 can use during its upgrade. In prepare_upgrade (controllerconfig/upgrades/management.py) copy the admin.conf file into /opt/platform/config/N+1/kubernetes.
- Before controller-1 generates its "regular" hiera data (from upgrade_controller in controllerconfig/upgrades/controller.py), it can copy the admin.conf file from /opt/platform to /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf. That way the puppet plugins that need to access the kubernetes API should all work without modification.

This change would probably also eliminate the need for the special call to self._config_update_hosts above as we could also generate the join command from controller-1.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: That's not how lower-constraints works. 'lower-constraints.txt' should list *all* dependencies including those brought in by other dependencies. In this case, a quick 'pip freeze' on a fresh tox virtualenv created from master does not include 'mock' so this is correct. In general though, you will have more entries in 'lower-constraints.txt' than in 'requirements.txt' and 'test-requirements.txt'

openstackclient/image/v2/image.py.message: Removing this makes it no longer an error to attempt to save an empty image.  I actually agree with the change but it needs to be release-noted.

I would really like to be able to continue to pipe images to stdin and not locally buffer them whenever possible.  Maybe we need a switch for one or the other behaviours?  It would be OK to throw an error if the back-end can not support that (Swift case).

If the SDK simply can not do that, nor wants to, I'm OK to carry that code in the openstackclient.api bits.  Can you tell I _really_ don't want to lose this ability?

Hrm. SO - there's a few things that might go south here. But I'm not *opposed* to handling this in the SDK.

Things like the swift backend case would need to throw an error like you mention - or, perhaps it's ok for someone to do single-threaded upload if they're reading from stdin anyway. Maybe we default to "raise error" but provide an sdk flag - and an OSC cli option to say "yeah, that's fine, just do a single thread"

We'd also not be able to do checksums in the way we are now - but we actually do already accumulate them, so maybe that's ok too.

In any case - if someone wants to figure out how to add this to the currently-absurd-pile-of-complicated-image code, I will absolutely not stop them. :)

This is a significant change in behaviour and needs to be at a minimum release-noted.  The use case for me was usually needing to decompress an image while uploading it, often due to space issues (20GB+ Windows images are not fun)
using `get` assumes you expect None, copy() won't work on it
